headline: Owls Fall in Four at Tulane
content: NEW ORLEANS ‚Äì Florida Atlantic volleyball drops a four-setter, 3-1 (25-17, 26-24, 18-25, 25-20) to the Tulane Green Wave on the road Friday at Avron B. Fogelman Arena. The Owls fall to 17-9 on the season and 8-5 in American play, while Tulane moves to 11-13 overall and 3-10 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED Tulane took the opening lead, holding a 15-11 advantage through the first set media break. The Owls battled back to within three, cutting the deficit to 18-15 after a kill from Kierstin Bevelle, but FAU couldn't close out the rally as the Green Wave captured the set on a 7-2 run to take the opening set 25-17. The Owls opened the second set strong, taking the opening lead at 4-1 Tulane answered back, cutting the Owls' lead to one at 7-6, however, Kayla Richardson helped spark a 4-0 Owl run with a kill and a block assist, along with a pair of Green Wave attacking errors to extend FAU's lead back to five, 11-6, pushing the Green Wave to call their first timeout of the set. Tulane cut the deficit in half shortly after, forcing the Owls to call a timeout of their own, holding a 13-11 lead. The Green Wave battled, eventually bringing the set even at 19-19. The Owls maintained the lead, holding a 23-22 advantage, but the Green Wave had late set success with a 4-1 run to earn the second set win, 26-24, and a two-set lead. Tulane held the early advantage in the third, opening the frame on an 8-5 run. However, following an FAU timeout, the Owls locked in to outscore the Green Wave 11-3 and take a five-point advantage at 16-11. The Owls fought and closed out the third set on a 6-5 run, as Anna Hartman registered the kill to take the third, 25-18. FAU fell behind quickly to open the fourth with Tulane building an 11-2 lead to open the frame. However, the Owls scored five unanswered points, capped off by a Zoe Winford kill, to cut the lead to four, 11-7. FAU kept the set within four through a 19-15 Tulane advantage, but couldn't close the gap with the Green Wave taking the fourth 25-20 for the match win. STATS & NOTES Olivia Hart and Bevelle led the way for the Owls. Hart finished with a team-best 14 kills, notching her 11th double-double of the season with 13 digs, as well as tying for a team-high two blocks and adding a pair of aces. Bevelle joined Hart in double-figures with 11 kills and added two digs and a block in the match. Emsley Venard once again dished out a team-leading 20 assists. Isabelle Northam recorded a team-best 18 digs. As a team, the Owls held advantages over the Green Wave in kills (52), assists (50), and service aces (8). UP NEXT The Owls will look to bounce back on Sunday, Nov. 9, as they visit conference leader Rice for a 2 p.m. ET first serve inside Tudor Fieldhouse and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Take Homecoming Game Versus Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Behind three touchdowns from Easton Messer and three takeaways from the defense, the Florida Atlantic football team defeated Tulsa in Saturday afternoon's Homecoming game at Flagler Credit Union Stadium by a score of 40-21. The Owls (4-5, 3-3) dropped 40 points at home for the third time this season with a complete game on both sides of the ball against the Golden Hurricane (2-7, 0-6), winning the turnover margin battle 3-1. VIDEO RECAP THE BEGINNING Starting out on defense, redshirt senior DB Terez Reid picked off a pass on the second play of the game, the Owls' first interception of the year. FAU's first drive on offense culminated in a 39-yard field goal by Garrison Smith, extending its program record to six consecutive games with a score on the opening possession. After a goal-line stand on defense, redshirt junior QB Caden Veltkamp continued his growing connection with redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt, hitting him down the sideline where Platt took it 47 yards for a touchdown and a 10-0 lead. THE TURNING POINT Following two Tulsa field goals early in the second, Veltkamp found a wide-open Messer for a 44-yard score to up the score to 17-6, the first of 21 unanswered points to close the half. It was then redshirt senior DB Damarius McGhee's turn to make a game-changing play, scooping up a fumble at the goal line and returning it 95 yards for the score. With the defense back on the field, senior DB Chris Keys Jr. made an interception to give it right back to the Owls, setting up the second score to Messer on an 11-yard strike to send FAU to the locker room up 31-6. THE FINISH After a quiet third quarter, a drive commanded by graduate QB Zach Gibson gave the Owls 40. A 30-yard grab from Platt on 4th-and-one flea flicker set up Messer's nine-yard score, his third of the day. Two sacks ‚Äì one by junior DE Deshaun Batiste and the other by freshman DE Josh Roberts ‚Äì kept Tulsa out of the end zone the rest of the way. OFFENSE Messer's hat trick was the first multi-score game of his collegiate career. He becomes just the sixth receiver in program history to haul in three touchdown catches in a single game. For the second week in a row, Platt recorded a 100+ yard receiving game with 114 on five catches. Sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton logged the first 100+ yard game of his career, with 107 yards on just 11 carries. He ripped off a 50-yard run, the longest of his career, to end the first quarter. DEFENSE McGhee's 95-yard fumble return is the second longest in program history, yardage not seen since the second game in the 2001 inaugural season. Leading the way in tackles was redshirt junior Leon Hart Jr. with 12. Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky recorded 11 tackles, his fourth straight game in double digits. In addition to the three takeaways, the Owls' defensive unit forced three turnovers-on-downs, and recorded five sacks, eight tackles for loss and six pass breakups POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt Junior QB Caden Veltkamp Graduate QB Zach Gibson Redshirt Junior WR Easton Messer Redshirt Junior WR Jayshon Platt Graduate OL Alex Atcavage Redshirt Senior DB Terez Reid Redshirt Senior DB Damarius McGhee PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-8-2025) Tulsa at Florida Atlantic UP NEXT The Owls will travel for their final road game of the 2025 season, heading to New Orleans for a matchup with Tulane on Saturday, Nov. 15. Kickoff is at 4 p.m. ET on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Owls End the Night with Victory Over Charleston in Field of 68
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team opened up the Field of 68 Tip-Off with a wire-to-wire 94-77 victory over Charleston on Saturday evening at Liberty Arena. The Owls (2-0) jumped out to a double-digit lead over the Cougars (1-2) early and did not look back the rest of the way. In a typical balanced offensive showing under Head Coach John Jakus, six players scored in double figures, with all 13 who stepped onto the court recording points. FIRST HALF Like the previous game, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool opened scoring. Five straight points from redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams gave the Owls an early 12-3 lead, with a dunk from junior center Vincent Neugebauer putting the team ahead by double digits. The lead grew to as big as 19, with a late shot from junior guard Kanaan Carlyle sending the Owls to the locker room with a 48-32 advantage. Defensively, Florida Atlantic did not surrender a field goal to four Charleston starters, holding them to a combined 0-for-11 shooting. SECOND HALF Two triples from junior forward Xander Pintelon put Florida Atlantic up by 20 five minutes in the second half. The Owls then worked their way in the paint, with sophomore Maxim Logue connecting on four shots in a four-minute span. Florida Atlantic led by as much as 25 and reached the 90-point mark with a three-pointer from redshirt freshman Liam Dayco-Green in his collegiate debut. PRESS CONFERENCES STATS & NOTES The Owls made the most of their second chance opportunities, outscoring the Cougars 24-7. Florida Atlantic converted 11 shots behind the arc, their second straight game with 10+ to open the season. Carlyle led the team in scoring for the second game in a row, this time with 14. Logue shot a perfect six-for-six from the field. Vanterpool had another balanced statline, logging six rebounds and five assists. Three Owls recorded the first points of their collegiate careers: Neugebauer, redshirt freshman guards Amar Amkou, and Dayco-Green FAU holds a 4-1 record in the Field of 68 Tip-Off. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will close the Field of 68 Tip-Off, facing host team Liberty on Sunday, Nov. 9. Tipoff is at 6 p.m. on the Field of 68's YouTube channel. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Jackson‚Äôs Buzzer-Beater Seals Road Win at Kennesaw State
content: KENNESAW, Ga. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team moves to 2-0 on the season, notching Coach Freeland's first road win at Florida Atlantic with a 69-68 victory over Kennesaw State on Saturday at VyStar Arena. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls trailed for much of the first quarter before Michiyah Simmons tied it at 10 with 4:33 left to go in the first. The game began to pick up speed, going back and forth, ending the first quarter with Florida Atlantic leading 19-16 off a Destyne Jackson 3-pointer. FAU started the second quarter strong, extending their lead to 26-19 in the first two minutes. Kennesaw State cut the Florida Atlantic lead to three at 29-26 by the media timeout. Jackson put the Owls' lead back to six with 30 seconds remaining in the half. The Owls entered halftime with a 37-31 lead. To start the third quarter, Kennesaw State committed three team fouls, and the Owls' lead extended to 10, 41-31, within the first minute of play. KSU began to close the lead before a Grace Carstensen 3-pointer extended the lead back to seven. The Owls then gained their largest lead of the contest at the six-minute mark with the score standing at 51-40. FAU held its lead at nine through the end of the third, taking a 61-52 lead into the final 10 minutes of play. Kennesaw State made a run in the fourth quarter, keeping Florida Atlantic from scoring for over two minutes. The Owls' lead shrank to one point, sitting at 64-63 with 3:48 to go in the game. KSU took the lead with two minutes to go in the game before Jackson called game with a corner 3-pointer with two seconds left to capture the win, 69-68. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we played really well for the first three quarters, and then the fatigue set in a little bit, but I'm extremely proud of the fight and the grit to finish the game. Destyne's shot at the end of the fourth was huge. Just really proud of our team effort and our belief that we would pull it out." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Four Florida Atlantic players finished in double figures. Jackson with 13, Simmons with 12, Jess Moors with 11, and Carstensen with 10. Vivian Onugha led the team in rebounds on the night with four. Simmons had a team-leading five assists. The Owls were 50 percent from both field goal and 3-point range on the night, matching up well to Kennesaw State's 48.1 field goal percentage and 16.7 three-point percentage. UP NEXT The Owls head to Coral Gables to face Miami on Thursday, Nov. 13, at 7 p.m. inside the Watsco Center on ACC Network Extra. FOLLOW THE OWLS For updates, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Drop Three-Setter at Rice
content: HOUSTON ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic Volleyball battled tough against conference leader Rice, but the Owls fell in three sets, 3-0 (25-20, 25-19, 26-24), on the road Sunday in Houston. The Owls fall to 17-10 overall and 8-6 in American play, while Rice moves to 17-8 on the season and 13-1 in league play. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls took the early lead 2-0, scoring back-to-back points off a kill from Anna Hartman and a Rice attacking error. Florida Atlantic maintained an advantage through a 10-9 lead after a Rice service error, however, Rice produced a 5-1 run to take its first lead of the set, 14-11. FAU scored three unanswered points off a pair of kills from Olivia Hart and Kayla Richardson, as well as a hitting error, but Rice retook the lead 15-14 at the first set media timeout. Out of the break, another Rice service error and a kill from Hart put the Owls back in front, 16-15. However, a 5-0 Rice run shifted the lead once again, 20-16, forcing a pair of timeouts from the Owls. Rice closed the set on a 5-4 run to take the opening 1-0 lead. After battling through a 9-9 stalemate to open set two, Rice scored nine unanswered points to break away to an 18-9 advantage. The Owls battled back, producing a 5-1 run to cut the deficit to five, 19-14, forcing Rice to call its first timeout of set two. However, the Owls couldn't muster another run as they traded points throughout the remainder of the set, as Rice eventually took the second set 25-19 for the two-set lead. FAU took the lead to open set three, holding an 11-9 advantage after a kill from Hartman and a block from Kierstin Bevelle and Libby Ashline. Rice retook the lead 14-12 after a 5-1 run, but FAU responded to take the lead back, eventually holding a 23-21 advantage. The Owls held set point at 24-23, but a service error and two attacking errors closed out the match as Rice took the set 26-24 to claim the three-set match. STATS & NOTES Hart and Hartman paced the Owls in the match, recording 11 and 10 kills, respectively. Emsley Venard dished out a team-high 17 assists across the three sets. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, recording a team-high 12 digs. Bevelle paced the Owls' block, tallying a team-best three blocks in the match. UP NEXT The Owls return home next week, hosting South Florida on Wednesday, Nov. 12, before closing the regular season against UTSA on Friday, Nov. 14, for Senior Day. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Defeated by Flames to Split Field of 68 Tip-Off
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team dropped the 2025 Field of 68 Tip-Off finale to Liberty by a score of 88-68 on Sunday evening. While the Flames (3-0) handed the Owls (2-1) their first loss of the season, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool impressed with a career high 24-point performance, shooting 10-for-15 from the field. FIRST HALF For the third game in a row, Vanterpool converted the first field goal make for the Owls for his first two of 10 points in the opening period. FAU kept the game within single digits for the first 12 minutes before surrendering a three-pointer to fall behind 31-19. Continuing to find success off offensive rebounds, Florida Atlantic outscored Liberty 13-2 on second chance points in the first half. The Owls closed a 20-point deficit with a 9-2 run before entering the locker room at halftime trailing 48-30. SECOND HALF Vanterpool continued where he left off with a three-pointer to open second-half scoring. He scored eight of the Owls' first nine points, including a three-point play. Junior guard Kanaan Carlyle attacked the hoop with all eight of his points coming in the final 20 minutes. PRESS CONFERENCE STATS & NOTES Vanterpool's 24 points doubles his previous career high of 12. Sophomore forward Maxim Logue made three out of his four field goal attempts. He finished the Field of 68 Tip-Off, shooting a combined nine-for-10 from the field. Redshirt freshman guard Amar Amkou scored a career-best eight points in six minutes of action. Florida Atlantic won the rebounding battle 34-28. The Owls outscored the Flames 11-2 on fastbreak points. UP NEXT The Owls will have a week off before returning to Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Monday, Nov. 17, for a meeting with Coastal Georgia. Tipoff is at 7 p.m. on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Beach Volleyball Wraps Fall at AVCA Fall National Championships
content: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic beach volleyball team wrapped up fall play this weekend at the AVCA Fall Beach National Championships. Kendall Mignerey and Reese Edwards represented the Owls in Huntsville. The duo was seeded No. 54 in the 64-team field. On Friday, Mignerey and Edwards fell in their opening-round match against No. 11 Texas' Lily Dee Davis and Madison White, 21-17, 21-14. The duo finished the opening day against No. 22-seed Florida State's Jessica Horwath and Elena Lam, falling in a three-set battle, 21-18, 18-21, 15-11. On Saturday, the pair picked up their first win of the weekend, defeating No. 59 Jacksonville's Hayden Garnett and Meredith Mrukowski in straight sets, 21-15, 21-19. Mignerey and Edwards advanced in the 49th-place bracket to take on No. 62 Houston Christian's Alexa Landmark and Olivia Zeigler, however, HCU took the win in three sets, 22-20, 21-10, 15-11. The pair closed out play on Sunday in the 53rd-place bracket, falling to No. 26 Stetson's Katie Camp and Madeline Camp, 21-15, 21-19. FOLLOW THE SANDY OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic Beach Volleyball, follow @FAUBeachVB on X and Instagram, or like FAU Beach Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Win South Florida Diving Invite
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic men's and women's diving teams wrapped up the two-day South Florida Diving Invitational hosted by FIU, sweeping both competitions. Junior Trevor Kuhn won two of the three events over the course of the two-day meet, victorious on the platform and 1mtr diving competitions. Miles Buchart was the meet's highest individual scorer with 37.00 total points. On the women's side, senior Grace Powell totaled 31.00 total individual points, tied for most on the women's side. RESULTS (MEN): 1. Florida Atlantic: 162.00 2. Keiser: 28.00 (WOMEN): 1. Florida Atlantic: 125.00 2. FIU: 118.00 3. Keiser: 43.00 4. St Thomas: 15.00 ON DECK The Owls will have a few weeks off before gearing up for the Patriot Midseason Invitational hosted by George Mason. The three-day meet begins on Wednesday, Nov. 19 with competition wrapping up on Saturday, Nov. 22. FAU will be looking for a third consecutive team sweep of the meet. SCHEDULE For the full 2025-26 swim & dive schedule, click HERE. ROSTER For the full 2025-26 swim & dive roster, click HERE. OWLS ON SOCIAL MEDIA For complete coverage of FAU swimming & diving, follow us on social media (@FAUSWIMDIVE)

headline: Owls Take Homecoming Game Versus Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Behind three touchdowns from Easton Messer and three takeaways from the defense, the Florida Atlantic football team defeated Tulsa in Saturday afternoon's Homecoming game at Flagler Credit Union Stadium by a score of 40-21. With the defense back on the field, senior DB Chris Keys Jr. made an interception to give it right back to the Owls, setting up the second score to Messer on an 11-yard strike to send FAU to the locker room up 31-6. THE FINISH After a quiet third quarter, a drive commanded by graduate QB Zach Gibson gave the Owls 40. A 30-yard grab from Platt on 4th-and-one flea flicker set up Messer's nine-yard score, his third of the day. Two sacks ‚Äì one by junior DE Deshaun Batiste and the other by freshman DE Josh Roberts ‚Äì kept Tulsa out of the end zone the rest of the way. OFFENSE Messer's hat trick was the first multi-score game of his collegiate career. He becomes just the sixth receiver in program history to haul in three touchdown catches in a single game. For the second week in a row, Platt recorded a 100+ yard receiving game with 114 on five catches. Sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton logged the first 100+ yard game of his career, with 107 yards on just 11 carries. He ripped off a 50-yard run, the longest of his career, to end the first quarter. DEFENSE McGhee's 95-yard fumble return is the second longest in program history, yardage not seen since the second game in the 2001 inaugural season. Leading the way in tackles was redshirt junior Leon Hart Jr. with 12. Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky recorded 11 tackles, his fourth straight game in double digits. In addition to the three takeaways, the Owls' defensive unit forced three turnovers-on-downs, and recorded five sacks, eight tackles for loss and six pass breakups POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt Junior QB Caden Veltkamp Graduate QB Zach Gibson Redshirt Junior WR Easton Messer Redshirt Junior WR Jayshon Platt Graduate OL Alex Atcavage Redshirt Senior DB Terez Reid Redshirt Senior DB Damarius McGhee PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-8-2025) Tulsa at Florida Atlantic UP NEXT The Owls will travel for their final road game of the 2025 season, heading to New Orleans for a matchup with Tulane on Saturday, Nov. 15. Kickoff is at 4 p.m. ET on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Florida Atlantic Hosts Ring Ceremony
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic softball gathered on Saturday morning to celebrate the success of the 2025 season, with the Owls receiving championship rings for their second consecutive American Conference regular season title and NCAA Tournament appearance. After becoming the school's first American Conference champion in 2024, the softball program won back-to-back titles in 2025, achieving 45 wins and a 23-4 conference record. Under third-year Head Coach Jordan Clark, the Owls qualified for the Gainesville Regional for the second year in a row and earned a 5-4 victory over Georgia Tech, their first in an NCAA Regional since 2016. Championship rings were distributed and the award-winning Owls from the previous campaign were recognized, including All-American pitcher Autumn Courtney, American Defensive Player of the Year Jesiana Mora, and All-Conference players Chloe Yeatts, Kylie Hammonds, Ainsley Lambert, Bella Foran, and Destiny Johns. The Owls were honored later in the afternoon at the football Homecoming game as part of the celebration of Florida Atlantic Varsity Champions. headline: Owls Fall in Four at Tulane
content: NEW ORLEANS ‚Äì Florida Atlantic volleyball drops a four-setter, 3-1 (25-17, 26-24, 18-25, 25-20) to the Tulane Green Wave on the road Friday at Avron B. Fogelman Arena. The Owls fall to 17-9 on the season and 8-5 in American play, while Tulane moves to 11-13 overall and 3-10 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED Tulane took the opening lead, holding a 15-11 advantage through the first set media break. The Owls battled back to within three, cutting the deficit to 18-15 after a kill from Kierstin Bevelle, but FAU couldn't close out the rally as the Green Wave captured the set on a 7-2 run to take the opening set 25-17. The Owls opened the second set strong, taking the opening lead at 4-1 Tulane answered back, cutting the Owls' lead to one at 7-6, however, Kayla Richardson helped spark a 4-0 Owl run with a kill and a block assist, along with a pair of Green Wave attacking errors to extend FAU's lead back to five, 11-6, pushing the Green Wave to call their first timeout of the set. Tulane cut the deficit in half shortly after, forcing the Owls to call a timeout of their own, holding a 13-11 lead. The Green Wave battled, eventually bringing the set even at 19-19. The Owls maintained the lead, holding a 23-22 advantage, but the Green Wave had late set success with a 4-1 run to earn the second set win, 26-24, and a two-set lead. Tulane held the early advantage in the third, opening the frame on an 8-5 run. However, following an FAU timeout, the Owls locked in to outscore the Green Wave 11-3 and take a five-point advantage at 16-11. The Owls fought and closed out the third set on a 6-5 run, as Anna Hartman registered the kill to take the third, 25-18. FAU fell behind quickly to open the fourth with Tulane building an 11-2 lead to open the frame. However, the Owls scored five unanswered points, capped off by a Zoe Winford kill, to cut the lead to four, 11-7. FAU kept the set within four through a 19-15 Tulane advantage, but couldn't close the gap with the Green Wave taking the fourth 25-20 for the match win. STATS & NOTES Olivia Hart and Bevelle led the way for the Owls. Hart finished with a team-best 14 kills, notching her 11th double-double of the season with 13 digs, as well as tying for a team-high two blocks and adding a pair of aces. Bevelle joined Hart in double-figures with 11 kills and added two digs and a block in the match. Emsley Venard once again dished out a team-leading 20 assists. Isabelle Northam recorded a team-best 18 digs. As a team, the Owls held advantages over the Green Wave in kills (52), assists (50), and service aces (8). UP NEXT The Owls will look to bounce back on Sunday, Nov. 9, as they visit conference leader Rice for a 2 p.m. ET first serve inside Tudor Fieldhouse and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.
